articles.headline: To Cut Costs, States Relax Prison Policies
articles.snippet: Forced to take a more pragmatic approach, states are now seeing prisoners as expenses to be reined in.
articles.abstract: Forced to take a more pragmatic approach, states are now seeing prisoners as expenses to be reined in.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARSON CITY, Nev.  For nearly three decades, most states have dealt with lawbreakers in two ways: lock more of them up for longer periods, and build more prisons to hold them. Now many governments, out of money and buried under mounting prison costs, are reversing those policies and practices.

articles.headline: As Clinton Visits Mexico, Strains Show in Relations
articles.snippet: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton will pay a visit Wednesday to an unhappy neighbor that blames America for many of its problems.
articles.abstract: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton will pay a visit Wednesday to an unhappy neighbor that blames America for many of its problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY  Mexico’s economy is being dragged down by the recession to the north. American addicts have turned Mexico into a drug superhighway, and its police and soldiers are under assault from American guns. Nafta promised 15 years ago that Mexican trucks would be allowed on American roads, but Congress said they were unsafe.
articles.byline: By Marc Lacey and Ginger Thompson

articles.headline: U.S. Weighs Sharif as Partner in Pakistan
articles.snippet: The Obama administration must decide whether Nawaz Sharif is likely to be a reliable ally or an obstructionist force.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration must decide whether Nawaz Sharif is likely to be a reliable ally or an obstructionist force.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan  The opposition leader, Nawaz Sharif, sealed his place as the most popular politician in Pakistan this month when he defied his house detention and led a triumphant protest that forced the government to restore the country’s chief justice.

articles.headline: U.S. Seeks Expanded Power in Seizing Firms
articles.snippet: The Obama administration and the Fed pressed to expand their power to seize troubled financial institutions.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration and the Fed pressed to expand their power to seize troubled financial institutions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration and the Federal Reserve, still smarting from the political furor over the bailout of American International Group, began a full-court press on Tuesday to expand the federal government’s power to seize control of troubled financial institutions deemed too big to fail.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Eric Dash

articles.headline: In a Volatile Time, Obama Strikes a New Tone
articles.snippet: In the president’s news conference, Americans saw the return of Barack Obama the lecturer.
articles.abstract: In the president’s news conference, Americans saw the return of Barack Obama the lecturer.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  For just under an hour on Tuesday night, Americans saw not the fiery and inspirational speaker who riveted the nation in his address to Congress last month, or the conversational president who warmly engaged Americans in talks across the country, or even the jaunty and jokey president who turned up on Jay Leno.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Adam Nagourney

articles.headline: Top Hedge Fund Managers Do Well in a Down Year
articles.snippet: Alpha magazine’s rankings show that the top earners took in $11.6 billion by trading above the pain in 2008.
articles.abstract: Alpha magazine’s rankings show that the top earners took in $11.6 billion by trading above the pain in 2008.
articles.lead_paragraph: The financial crisis may have turned much of Wall Street’s wealth into dross, but a select group of hedge fund managers has managed to maintain a golden touch that might make King Midas blush.

articles.headline: The Start of a Crisis, Through the Lens of Avis
articles.snippet: Policy makers keep trying to connect the financial crisis to the day-to-day economy, but their examples tend to be hypothetical.
articles.abstract: Policy makers keep trying to connect the financial crisis to the day-to-day economy, but their examples tend to be hypothetical.
articles.lead_paragraph: Timothy Geithner, Ben Bernanke and President Obama have been trying to persuade us that the latest financial rescue plan is meant to help us, not Wall Street. The goal, as Mr. Geithner said Monday, is to fix the markets for “small-business lending, large-business borrowing, consumer borrowing, auto finance, student loans, et cetera.”

articles.headline: Dissecting Bank Plan for a Way to Profit
articles.snippet: Bankers and traders have begun the complex financial calculus of the latest bank rescue plan, with a goal of finding ways to profit from it.
articles.abstract: Bankers and traders have begun the complex financial calculus of the latest bank rescue plan, with a goal of finding ways to profit from it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Up and down Wall Street, bankers and traders sharpened their pencils on Tuesday as they began the complex financial calculus of the latest bank rescue plan. Their goal: to find ways to profit from it.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Mary Williams Walsh

articles.headline: Insurers Offer to Soften a Key Rate-Setting Policy
articles.snippet: The health insurance industry said it was willing to stop charging higher premiums to sick people if Congress were to require that all Americans carry insurance.
articles.abstract: The health insurance industry said it was willing to stop charging higher premiums to sick people if Congress were to require that all Americans carry insurance.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The health insurance industry said Tuesday that it was willing to end the practice of charging higher premiums to sick people if Congress adopted a comprehensive plan requiring all Americans to carry insurance.

articles.headline: A Health Plan for All and the Concerns It Raises
articles.snippet: A plan that would resemble Medicare but be open to all Americans is raising questions and concerns for insurers, doctors and legislators.
articles.abstract: A plan that would resemble Medicare but be open to all Americans is raising questions and concerns for insurers, doctors and legislators.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is one of the most contentious health care proposals President Obama has floated: offer a federal, Medicare-like insurance plan to anyone, at any age. And let commercial insurers offer their private health plans alongside it.

articles.headline: Weak Demand at Treasury Auction Gives Wall Street Pause
articles.snippet: Stocks lost ground but recovered after a weak auction of government debt stirred worries about how easily Washington will be able to raise money to fund its economic rescue program.
articles.abstract: Stocks lost ground but recovered after a weak auction of government debt stirred worries about how easily Washington will be able to raise money to fund its economic rescue program.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an early sign that Washington may have to pay more to finance huge stimulus plans to fix the economy, investors hesitated at buying a government debt issue on Wednesday, forcing the Treasury to pay a higher interest rate than expected.
